document.topic_text: Local firefighters finally conquer Mt. Denali summit Tarrant County firefighters take on Denali Todd Unger, WFAA 10:58 PM. CDT August 11, 2016 Clint Brewer and Alex Cramer reached the summit of Mt. Denali on July 4. (Photo: WFAA) FORT WORTH -- The days were long, the nights cold, and the outcome far from certain. But two Tarrant County firefighters with dreams of conquering North America's tallest peak have finally succeeded. "I've done some fun things as a firefighter, but being on top of Denali was a dream come true for me," Clint Brewer said. Brewer, 36, is a Fort Worth firefighter. In late June, he and Arlington firefighter Alex Cramer set off for Mt. Denali in Alaska. After months of training lugging around 60-pound backpacks and weights, the two men thought there were ready to ascend a mountain that has alluded so many. Clint Brewer (Photo: WFAA) "For me, I was thinking about that," Brewer said. "I mean, I tried before." In 2014, News 8 documented the journey of a group of local firefighters that spent days trying to reach Denali's summit. It was ultimately a five-day blizzard that snowed them in at the mountain's high camp and prevented reaching the peak. This time, there was no blizzard. Brewer's GoPro video shows the view from the top. (Photo: Courtesy - Clint Brewer) "The last 30 minutes, you're just walking up this slight ridge, and you're walking right to it," Brewer said. "It's amazing." For Cramer, who had experience trekking up some of Colorado's famous 14ers, the experience took climbing to another level. "When we got to 17,000 feet, I started feeling nauseous, like I was going to throw up all over the place," he said, laughing. By the time the firefighter brothers were ready to attempt the summit, though, Cramer was well acclimated and ready to go. Celebration as they reached the summit. (Photo: Courtesy - Clint Brewer) "It happened on July 4," he said. "It was incredible. At some points, there are 3,000 foot drops on this side, 3,000 drops on that side." Both men climbed on behalf of The Warm Place , a local charity that supports grieving children. They helped raise more than $20,000 for the group. Brewer says he wants to return to Denali. Cramer says once might be good enough for him. "There are other places to try," he said. Copyright 2016 WFAA
